baseline_groups.claim_summary: Teams cooperate more (or differently) than individuals in finitely repeated Prisoner Dilemma games, as measured by the cooperation rate.
baseline_groups.notes: The baseline uses the full sample with Block FE and Round FE, clustered at the player level. The paper finds a small positive but insignificant effect (+1.5pp, p=0.74). Expected sign is unknown because the paper documents both directions depending on game phase.

global_notes: This paper studies team vs individual play in repeated PD. The core claim is about the average cooperation rate difference (is_team -> cooperate). The specification search also includes defection timing outcomes (coop_end_round on a different dataset), alternative game-theoretic outcomes (mutual_coop, mutual_defect, got_suckered, temptation, payoff), a placebo with fake_team treatment, and extensive heterogeneity by block and round. The defection timing analysis uses a different dataset and outcome concept, so it is classified as non-core. Many heterogeneity specs restrict to single blocks or rounds, testing subgroup effects rather than the average treatment effect.
